video.title: Realtor plays hide-and-seek, uses ASMR on viral listing videos

bylines.description:
Erika Gonzalez anchors News4 Midday on NBC4 and serves as a Live Desk and breaking news anchor for the station's evening newscasts and streaming channels.

During the week, Gonzalez's 4 Your Home reports help viewers understand the real estate market while improving the look and feel of their homes. Gonzalez also serves as the editorial lead for a franchise on NBC4's sister station, Telemundo 44. The regular segment, Bebé Tips, supports the needs of parents with young children through access to premier specialists answering their most common questions.

Gonzalez started her career in her native Texas, where she anchored newscasts on KEYE-TV and Telemundo Austin as well as XRIO-TV in the Rio Grande Valley. She has called NBC4 and Washington, D.C., home since 2011.

Gonzalez holds a degree in Communications from the University of Texas-Pan American, now known as UT Rio Grande Valley.

She is an Emmy-Award winning journalist who lives with her husband and daughter in Washington, D.C.

You can email story ideas to her at Erika.Gonzalez@nbcuni.com and follow her on Twitter @Erika_news.

bylines.display_name: Patricia Fantis, News4 senior producer for special projects

content_blocks.rendered: A local realtor is creating a roar on social media with a whisper.
Lisa DuBois, a RE/MAX realtor in business for 20 years, uses her social media platforms to promote her listings. Recently, she found a creative and unique way to get more traction.
A few months ago, she decided that due to the heaviness of the world around us, her videos could use something fun, so she partnered with brand strategist Eric Cruz.
Cruz wanted to personalize DuBois' social media videos. First, he asked her how seriously she took herself.
"Not at all,” DuBois replied.
Her answer led Cruz to suggest playing hide-and-seek in her listings. Now, they've become a viral sensation. One video already has over 13 million views.
DuBois showcases her properties with a now-signature style, playing hide-and-seek while using autonomous sensory meridian response (ASMR), as she whispers.

“I had to learn (ASMR)," she said. "That first meeting with Eric, he said, ‘OK, great. We’re gonna have some fun. Let’s do some ASMR.’ And I was like, ‘Sure, what is it?’ And he wanted me to tap my fingernails on the counter, but my fingernails are too short. So, he said, 'OK. We're gonna whisper.”
News4 couldn't let DuBois leave without making our own hide-and-seek video at the station.
Partnering with Cruz helps DuBois' videos pop, leading to great numbers.

“Usually, the hide-and-seek videos are like 10-20 minutes," Cruz said. "It probably takes me that same amount of time to edit them. Sometimes, I'll be like, Oh my God! This needs to come out, like, right now, and I'll go out in my car for a second and edit real quick.”
DuBois said those views translate to clicks on her listings in D.C. and Virginia.

“A lot of follow-up calls from other agents going, 'How many more leads? How many more sales?'" she said. "And none, yet. I've got a very, very solid real estate business. I did this for fun. This was to make myself laugh.”
Get the D.C. area's top news and weather delivered to your inbox every morning. Sign up for First & 4Most, our free newsletter.

items.title: The politics of real estate: How will the election affect DC-area housing?
items.summary: In January, when a new president and new lawmakers are sworn in, new White House staff and congressional aides will come with them. That means new prospective homebuyers — but with interest rates still above 6% and the rental market up a quarter, will we see more buying or renting?

meta.video_captions: live for us in Landover. Darcy. Thank you. You know, every election year in Washington, it’s not just the offices on Pennsylvania Avenue that can change hands. So too can the homes in our local real estate market today. News 4’s Erika Gonzalez takes a look at the politics of real estate and what the market could do when a new administration takes the helm. The ballots are close to being counted, and in January, when a new president and lawmakers are sworn in, new White House staff and congressional aides will come with them. That means new prospective home buyers. But with interest rates still above 6% and the rental market up a quarter, will we see more buying or renting? It’s a big misconception generally that there’s just this humongous seismic shift in Washington when administrations change in housing. Daniel Heider is with Heider Real Estate and TTR Sotheby’s. He says you can almost bank on seeing a rise in the rental market. Folks think that every time, you know, an administration turns over that, you know, there’s just a mass exodus and ton of new people coming in that are supporting the federal government, right? For the most part, the staffers that are working for, you know, a lot of the government organizations, these are not folks that are in a position to just come in and purchase real estate off the bat. They want to familiarize themselves with the area. They also don’t know if they’re going to be in the area for the next, you know, four years. So there’s a lot of uncertainty. According to the National Association of Realtors, which has been tracking real estate trends in election years since the 80s, presidential elections have a positive effect on the housing market nationwide, but the impact is even more significant in the Washington, D.C. Metro region, with a 10% increase in home sales. The years after an election. Election or not, interest rates come down. We’re going to see consumer confidence go up. We’re going to see affordability go up and that is going to change our market in a big way. We expect a big fall market. And I think following that, we’re going to see a big spring market as well. While housing inventory is increasing, it’s still tough out there. Nar finds that median home prices in the DMV go up an average of 5% the year after an election. And if you’re wondering what those in the White House will buy up, Heider says the 2016 election in the cabinet of high ranking notables with deep pockets is the exception, not the norm. What I can say, if we look at the past for what what was the Trump administration? We saw a big climb in our our very high end luxury market. They were already used to major metropolitan markets like New York, like San Francisco, like Miami, where their neighborhoods you know, saw a ten, 20, 15, $50 million homes all day long. You come to a market like the Capital Region, D.C, Maryland and Virginia, and a $5 million option looks like a real value proposition. Nar adds that when it comes to the presidential race or the election year as a whole, results may tilt the market one way or the other. But

video.title: The politics of real estate in the DC area

bylines.description:
Erika Gonzalez anchors News4 Midday on NBC4 and serves as a Live Desk and breaking news anchor for the station's evening newscasts and streaming channels.

During the week, Gonzalez's 4 Your Home reports help viewers understand the real estate market while improving the look and feel of their homes. Gonzalez also serves as the editorial lead for a franchise on NBC4's sister station, Telemundo 44. The regular segment, Bebé Tips, supports the needs of parents with young children through access to premier specialists answering their most common questions.

Gonzalez started her career in her native Texas, where she anchored newscasts on KEYE-TV and Telemundo Austin as well as XRIO-TV in the Rio Grande Valley. She has called NBC4 and Washington, D.C., home since 2011.

Gonzalez holds a degree in Communications from the University of Texas-Pan American, now known as UT Rio Grande Valley.

She is an Emmy-Award winning journalist who lives with her husband and daughter in Washington, D.C.

You can email story ideas to her at Erika.Gonzalez@nbcuni.com and follow her on Twitter @Erika_news.
bylines.excerpt: Erika Gonzalez anchors News4 Midday on NBC4 and serves as a Live Desk and breaking news anchor for the station’s evening newscasts and streaming channels. During the week, Gonzalez’s 4 Your Home reports help viewers understand the real estate market while improving the look and feel of their homes. Gonzalez also serves as the editorial lead for a franchise on...

content_blocks.rendered: Every election year in D.C., it’s not just the offices on Pennsylvania Avenue that can change hands. So, too, can the homes in the local real estate market.

In January, when a new president and new lawmakers are sworn in, new White House staff and congressional aides will come with them. That means new prospective homebuyers — but with interest rates still above 6% and the rental market up a quarter, will we see more buying or renting?

"It's a big misconception, generally, that there's just this humongous seismic shift in Washington when administrations change, in housing," said Daniel Heider with Heider Real Estate and TTR Sotheby’s.
He said we can almost bank on seeing a rise in the rental market.

"Folks think that every time, you know, an administration turns over that, you know, there's just a mass exodus and a ton of new people coming in that are supporting the federal government," Heider said. "For the most part, the staffers that are working for, you know, a lot of the government organizations, these are not folks that are in a position to just come in and purchase real estate off the bat."
"They want to familiarize themselves with the area," he said. "They also don't know if they're going to be in the area for the next four years ... so there's a lot of uncertainty."

According to the National Association of Realtors (NAR), which has been tracking real estate trends in election years since the '80s, presidential elections have a positive effect on the housing market nationwide. But the impact is even more significant in the D.C. metro area, with a 10% increase in home sales the year after an election.

Hispanic Heritage Month Oct 24, 2024

Being a voice: How one Venezuela native became a trailblazer at the White House

Capital One Arena Oct 20, 2024

DC mayor proposes legislation to buy Capital One Arena for $87.5 million

"Election or not, interest rates come down. We're going to see consumer confidence go up," Heider said. "We're going to see affordability go up. And that is going to change our market in a big way. We expect a big fall market. And I think following that, we're going to see a big spring market as well."
With the Washington Capitals and Wizards staying downtown after all, and crime on a downward trend, Axios reports a renewed interest in properties downtown.
But while housing inventory is increasing, it's still tough out there. In addition, NAR finds that median home prices in the D.C. area increase by an average of 5% percent the year after an election.
And, if you're wondering what people working in the White House will buy up, Heider says the 2016 election and the cabinet of high-ranking notables with deep pockets was the exception, not the norm.

"If we look at the past for what was the Trump administration, we saw a big climb in our very high-end luxury market," Heider said. "They were already used to major metropolitan markets like New York, like San Francisco, like Miami, where their neighborhoods, you know, saw $10-, $20-, $15-, $50-million homes all day long. You come to a market like the capital region, D.C., Maryland and Virginia, and a $5 million option looks like a real value proposition."

NAR adds that, when it comes to the presidential race, or election year as a whole, results may tilt the market one way or the other, but they say it’s not as important compared to mortgage rates and the changes to high-paying jobs.

Erika Gonzalez anchors News4 Midday on NBC4 and serves as a Live Desk and breaking news anchor for the station's evening newscasts and streaming channels.

During the week, Gonzalez’s 4 Your Home reports help viewers understand the real estate market while improving the look and feel of their homes. Gonzalez also serves as the editorial lead for a franchise on...

content_blocks.rendered: D.C. has a rich history in culture and politics – and also, helicopters.

A newly renovated condo in Columbia Heights was once the home of the first helicopters ever to take flight. The condo at 774 Girard St. NW was the original helicopter factory in D.C. It’s where Emil Berliner developed the gramophone, the record and components that allow helicopters to fly.
“It sat abandoned for years and years and years,” said Daniel Heider of Heider Real Estate and TTR Sotheby's International Realty.
News4's 4 Your Home got an exclusive look inside.
The helicopter manufacturing facility declined starting in the 1900s, which gave Brook Road Development an opportunity to breathe new life into the space and pay homage to its history, Heider said.
The renovated condo includes original photos of the helicopters that were made and designed in the factory. The space features the factory’s original red brick.
The condo is more than 5,000 square feet and has three bedrooms, three full bathrooms and a half-bathroom.
It hit the market Thursday and is listed at $3,250,000.

items.title: Trees have faces and fall is a great time to plant
items.summary: Did you know trees have faces? A landscape architect told News4’s Erika Gonzalez what to know as you get your yard ready for fall, in our 4 Your Home series.

meta.video_captions: tell us what you need to know to get you ready for fall. Trees can add interest. They can add privacy to your home and the fall is a great time to plant. I’m Erika Gonzalez, alongside landscape architect Joseph Richardson to talk about a few things to keep in mind when you are planting the season. Fall is a great time to plant, just like spring. And I would argue that it might actually be better than spring because trees, shrubs, perennials get a chance to establish a bit longer before getting hit with extreme summer heat and drought. Okay, so what to look for in a tree? How to plant it? Which direction? Even the soil. Let’s talk a little bit more about that. In the backyard of this home. Let’s do it. When we’re working with homeowners, we start to think about what is the function of the tree. Is this a tree that needs to provide privacy? Does it need to be evergreen or can it be deciduous with beautiful fall color? Is it a shade tree? And the other thing too is to keep in mind is just the same way that you would throw a paint swatch on the wall and then you’d stand back and you’d look at it to see if you like it. You could do the same thing with a tree, because trees, if you didn’t know this, actually have faces. Trees are living things just like we are, and there’s going to be more attractive sides of a particular tree and maybe less attractive sides. And so all things being equal, sometimes just a quarter of a turn of that tree, depending on how you’re going to view it, can really make a difference in how you perceive it. Another thing to keep in mind is the form. So here we’re under this beautiful canopy of trees and they have this really strong v like marking to them. Yeah. So here we’re under the canopy of some beautiful mature zelkova trees. These trees are about 15 years old and were chosen specifically for their branching pattern. What’s the watering schedule? How important is it to water a freshly planted, newly planted tree? There is nothing more important than watering a newly planted tree. Some of this can be seasonal, but generally speaking, every couple of days. Okay. More or less depending on the temperature. But one of the most important things that we try to impress on our clients is the soil moisture. So what we encourage is rather than a quick, heavy drenching, slower, longer irrigation is always better. But things to keep in

items.title: Wallpaper trends: How to transform your room in an instant
items.summary: Wallpaper doesn’t have to go on the walls to make a statement. News4’s Erika Gonzalez spoke with a local designer about the latest trends in wallpaper.

meta.video_captions: Wallpaper can transform a room Wallpaper can transform a room in an instant, and it doesn’t have to go on the walls to make a statement. News 4’s Erika Gonzalez spoke to a local designer to share the latest trends in wallpaper with budget friendly and kid friendly options for your home. Wallpaper is still very much a thing, but where you use it, the types of materials that encompass the wallpaper and how it holds up to wallpaper and how it holds up to kids. Those are all new things that we can talk about with interior designer Tracee Morris. Thanks so much for chatting with us. Thank you. First and foremost, you want something that will look nice, but that’s also going to hold up to sticky fingers. Tell me a little bit about what is kid proof. Wallpaper world has has a vinyl. It is fantastic. It looks like grass cloth. It actually if you have to go up and feel it, but it is 100% wipeable. So if those kids get those sticky fingers on there you are good as gold, no problem. The other thing too is about where you put wallpaper, and sometimes it can be the less is more approach. You don’t have to do four walls. You don’t have to do a wall to begin with at all. If you just want to give your space a little bit of texture, a little bit of something, start with the backs of a bookshelf. If you have moved into a home and it has a bookshelf and it just looks a little flat to you, add some beautiful texture. It doesn’t have to be a pattern, just give it a little color and a little texture. Well and you’re getting a lot of bang for your buck. You mentioned texture and that’s another big thing with wallpaper is whatever’s going to draw you in and make you want to touch and feel. That’s really in right now. Absolutely. We are seeing a lot of woods. They are actual woods that are veneered onto wallpaper, and it is unbelievable. They just make a space. You just want to go up and touch. You can’t even believe that they look so fantastic. Very fun. And the other thing that I noticed in some of the samples that you brought for us to look at is green. Green is a neutral, and that is the color of the season right now. Yes, it is one of those colors, especially one of those deeper, more Army has a brown base. Green okay. You can put it with anything, especially the white oak that’s happening right now. Everybody wants white oak, all of your furniture, all of your cabinets. You’re seeing that. So pair that with green and it’s like pairing a black

items.title: Pillow swap: Tips for picking the best accent pillows
items.summary: An interior design expert has tips for what to look for on your next venture for pillows. News4’s Erika Gonzalez reports.

meta.video_captions: And are looking forward to seeing you again here in DC. Well, as the seasons change, so does your home decor. Pillows can be the easiest thing to swap out, but with so many options, it can also be really hard to figure out what is actually best. Yeah, that’s why Eric Gonzalez is joining us with expert advice, revealing the top thing designers look for when thing designers look for when choosing pillows for your home. Before your next trip to HomeGoods or target, you’re going to want to see this. Pillows come in a variety of sizes, fabrics, and designs. So what looks best? I spoke to local designer Annie Elliott, who shares four things she’s always looking for when she goes pillow shopping. I’m Annie Elliott and I’m an interior designer here in Washington, D.C. accent pillows are everyone’s favorite accessory, and you can buy them just about anywhere. These days. But that is both good and bad. Good, because you have a lot to choose from in terms of size, style, color, but bad because the quality varies wildly here are some things to look for when you’re shopping for accent pillows. Look for a removable cover, especially with a zipper along one of the seams. That’s better than having an envelope in the back that’s much easier to clean than a full pillow. And if you damage the cover beyond repair, at least you still have the insert. Look for pillows that have a welt, a cord, or a fringe along the seam. That level of detail really elevates the look when it comes to inserts. Look for those that have a little bit of give. So feather and down are great if you’re not allergic down. Alternative has come a long way recently. You just want to make sure that those are not too springy. As for pillows sizes, the larger the piece of furniture, the larger the pillow If you have a huge sectional, 20 If you have a huge sectional, 20 inch square pillows are going to be perfect, but on a more petite chair, 16in is probably fine. When in doubt, go with 18in. That size works just about anywhere if you want your pillows to look really stuffed and stand up well, look for inserts that are an inch or two larger than the pillow cover. When it comes to mixing pillows, it really depends on your personal style. I like mixing floral pillows with stripes, maybe the occasional solid final word about accent pillows. No karate chopping please. Just plump them up and let them sit unsalted on your sofa, chair or bed. Happy pillow shopping! I always thought the karate chop was like the stylish thing to
